sen.j: 織部焼（おりべやき）は、桃山時代の天正年間（1573年-1592年）頃から、主に美濃国で産する陶器。
sen.e: Oribe ware is earthenware which have been produced mainly in Mino Province since Tensho era (1573-1592) of Momoyama period.

sen.j: 千利休の弟子であった大名茶人、古田織部の指導で創始され、織部好みの奇抜で斬新な形や文様の茶器などを多く産したことによる。
sen.e: It was named after Oribe FURUTA, daimyo (feudal lord) and a master of the tea ceremony who had been a disciple of SEN no Rikyu, because Oribe ware was born under his direction and many chaki (tea utensils) of wild, novel shape and pattern that are Oribe-Gonomi (Oribe's taste) were produced.
sen.cmt: 原文には「古田重然」とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「古田織部」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: It was named after Oribe FURUTA, who was a daimyo (feudal lord) and master of the tea ceremony and had been a disciple of SEN no Rikyu, because Oribe ware was born under his direction and many chaki (tea utensils) of eccentric, novel shapes and patterns according to Oribe's taste (Oribe-Gonomi) were produced.

sen.j: 釉薬の色などにより青織部、赤織部、黒織部、志野織部などがある。
sen.e: There are several kinds of Oribe ware according to glaze color and so on: ao-oribe (partially covered with green glaze), aka-oribe (combination of red and white clay), kuro-oribe (a type of oribe ware with black glaze), shino-oribe (a type of oribe ware utilizing techniques of e-shino, or printed shino ware) and so on.

sen.j: 整然とした端正な形を好み、抽象を重んじる他の茶器とは違い、歪んだ形の沓（くつかけ）茶碗や、市松模様や幾何学模様の絵付け、後代には扇子などの形をした食器や香炉など、具象的な物が多い。
sen.e: While other chaki are expected to be well-ordered and decent in shape, and also are valued for their abstraction; Oribe ware has many articles of concrete expression, such as Kutsukake chawan (tea bowl shaped like a shoe of old times) which is irregularly shaped, paintings of checkered or geometric pattern, and in later years tableware, koro (incense burner) and so on in shape of sensu (folding fan) and so on.

While other chaki are expected to be well-ordered and decent in shape and also are valued for their abstraction, Oribe ware include a number of representational articles, such as irregularly-shaped Kutsukake chawan (tea bowls shaped like a shoe of old times), those with a checkered or geometric-pattern hand painting, and in later years, tableware and incense burners in the shape of a sensu (folding fan) and the like.

sen.j: 登り窯の利用や、木型に湿らせた麻布を張り、そこに伸ばした粘土を押し付けるという手法で大量生産も行われた。
sen.e: Mass production was also conducted with the use of climbing kilns and the method of pressing the clay onto a wooden pattern covered with wet hemp cloth.
